resources.title: ğŸ›¡ï¸ Safety Resources
resources.subtitle: Everything you need to know to protect yourself online. Knowledge is your best defense.

phishing.title: Phishing & Smishing
phishing.description: Fake emails or texts pretending to be from banks, employers, or services you useâ€”trying to steal your login info or personal details.

techSupport.title: Tech Support Scams
techSupport.description: Pop-ups or calls claiming your computer has a virus. They want money for fake 'repairs' or remote access to steal your data.

prize.title: Prize & Lottery Scams
prize.description: Messages saying you won money or a prize you never entered to win. They'll ask for fees or personal info to 'claim' it.

fakeJob.title: Fake Job Offers
fakeJob.description: Jobs requiring no interview, offering high pay, or asking you to deposit checks and wire money back. Too easy = too fake.

romance.title: Romance Scams
romance.description: Fake online relationships where someone gains your trust, then invents emergencies to ask for money.

grandparent.title: Grandparent Scams
grandparent.description: Callers pretending to be a grandchild or family member in trouble, begging for money and secrecy.

investment.title: Investment Scams
investment.description: Promises of guaranteed high returns, often involving cryptocurrency. If it sounds too good to be true, it is.

debt.title: Debt Scams
debt.description: Fake collectors threatening legal action, or companies promising to erase debt for upfront fees.

redFlags.title: ğŸš© Red Flags to Watch For

urgency.detail: "Act NOW or your account will be closed!"

generic.detail: "Dear Customer" instead of your actual name

sender.detail: Look for misspellings like 'amaz0n' or weird domains

urls.detail: Hover before you clickâ€”where does it really go?

passwords.detail: Legitimate companies never ask for these via email/text

attachments.detail: Especially .exe, .zip, or files asking to 'enable macros'

emotional.detail: Fear, excitement, or sympathy designed to override your judgment

pause.title: Pause Before You Click
pause.text: Urgency is a scammer's weapon. Take a breath and think.

hover.title: Hover Over Links
hover.text: On desktop, hover to see where a link actually goes before clicking.

direct.title: Go Direct
direct.text: Type the website URL yourself instead of clicking links in messages.

verify.title: Verify by Phone
verify.text: Call companies using numbers from their official website or your card.

block.title: Block & Report
block.text: Don't engage with scammers. Block them and report to the platform.

twoFactor.title: Enable 2FA
twoFactor.text: Two-factor authentication adds an extra lock even if your password is stolen.

identityTheft.title: ğŸ†” Identity Theft
identityTheft.whatText: When someone uses your personal information (name, SSN, credit card) without permission.
warningItems: Bills for accounts you didn't open

passwords.title: ğŸ” Passwords & Security
passwords.strongText: 12+ characters mixing letters, numbers, and symbols. Never reuse passwords.
passwords.managerText: Apps that securely store and generate passwords so you don't have to remember them all.
passwords.twoFactorText: An extra verification step (like a text code) when logging in. Even if someone steals your password, they can't get in without the second factor.
passwords.tipText: Enable 2FA on all important accountsâ€”especially email, banking, and social media.

malware.title: ğŸ¦  Malware Defense
malware.description: Malware is malicious software that can steal your data, spy on you, or damage your device.
items: Only download from official app stores

misinformation.title: ğŸ” Spotting Misinformation
misinformation.description: False or misleading information spreads fast online. Before you believe or share:
items: Content making you angry? That's often the point.

faq.title: â“ What If...? (FAQ)
faq.subtitle: Click any question to see what you should do.

q1.question: What if I already clicked a suspicious link?
q1.answer: Don't panic. Close the page immediately without entering any information. Run a virus scan on your device. If you entered any passwords, change them right away starting with email and banking. Monitor your accounts for unusual activity.

q2.question: What if I gave someone my password?
q2.answer: Change that password immediately, plus any other accounts where you used the same password. Enable two-factor authentication. Contact the service (bank, email, etc.) to let them know. Monitor for suspicious activity.

q3.question: What if I sent money to a scammer?
q3.answer: Contact your bank or payment service (Venmo, CashApp, Zelle) immediatelyâ€”they may be able to stop or reverse the transaction. File a report at reportfraud.ftc.gov. Unfortunately, money sent via wire transfer or gift cards is very hard to recover.

q4.question: What if someone is asking me to keep something secret from my family?
q4.answer: This is a major red flag. Scammers use secrecy to isolate you. Real emergencies don't require hiding from family. Always verify by calling the person directly on a number you already haveâ€”not one they give you.

q5.question: What if a 'friend' on social media is asking for money?
q5.answer: Their account may be hacked. Contact them through a different method (call or text their real number) to verify it's actually them before sending anything. Real friends will understand you being careful.

q6.question: What if I think my identity has been stolen?
q6.answer: Go to IdentityTheft.gov (the official FTC resource) to report it and get a personalized recovery plan. Contact your bank and credit card companies. Consider placing a fraud alert or credit freeze with the three credit bureaus.

citizenship.title: ğŸŒ Be a Good Digital Citizen
citizenship.description: Online safety isn't just about protecting yourself. Think before you post, respect others' privacy, stand up against bullying, and remember: there's a real person behind every screen.
